Situation1: A violent assault is taking place in a public area, with bystanders in danger
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I stood in the crowded polling station, ballot in hand, listening as the election official explained the provisional ballot process. My registration didn’t match, and I had only ten minutes before the station closed. I felt the weight of my civic duty pressing on me—my vote mattered, and I wanted to do everything by the book. Just as I reached for the form, my radio crackled. Dispatch reported a violent assault just outside, only a block away. Bystanders were in danger, and I was the closest officer. My training screamed at me to act, to protect lives, to run toward the chaos. But the official’s eyes were on me, expecting me to finish the paperwork, to follow the rules like every other voter. My heart pounded as I looked from the form to the door, torn between my oath as a police officer and my right—and responsibility—as a citizen.
